Literature Review: The spinal cord is a complex neural network that plays a crucial role in motor control, particularly in locomotion. The intrinsic networks within the spinal cord enable animals to produce rhythmic, patterned movements even after the spinal cord has been severed from the brain. However, the underlying circuitry that produces these movements remains poorly understood due to the diversity of neuron classes and their patterns of interconnectivity. This review aims to provide an overview of the classes of spinal neurons, their interconnectivity, and the significance of their circuit connections along the long axis of the spinal cord. We will also discuss several lines of analysis to move toward a definitive understanding of the spinal network.
